Posts.Content: May 21, 2010 08:07AM hymil wrote: Hi KT and welcome. From what you have said, her tumour is too big to remove at the moment even with a mastectomy, and the idea of the hormones before surgery is to get that smaller. A smaller lump will be easier to take out, and has a better chance to get clear margins, since it's the risk of secondaries you really need to be thinking about. Also potential surgical problems like blood loss should be less, and if they are also dissecting the armpit for lymph-nodes that is much easier with a smaller lump. They might not need to do this, depending on the staging investigations, which would be great. I had the same thing, hormones before surgery, because my lump was large too, 6cm. The surgeon wanted to try for just a lumpectomy, but it didn't shrink enough, (still 6cm after 4 months tamoxifen) so I ended up with mastectomy anyway. Under a microscope afterwards they said you could tell the drug was working by how the cells looked, so I know the risk of spread has been reduced, and it also had given me time to get used to the idea and investigate the options. Actually it was more that the surgeons were trying to do breast-conserving because i'm under 50, i was like just Get-it-off-of-me-NOW !! They might be wanting extra time to get your grandma ready for surgery in other ways eg improve cardiac or lung-function, maybe build her up a bit. She will probably get the hormones after surgery as well, this seems to be fairly standard for Eostrogen-responding tumours. Especially as for her, the option for radiation has been used up already. Hope it all goes well for her, good luck!

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2011 03:57PM hymil wrote: There is a very  detailed page here about staging that i found useful when i was starting out last year. : http://www.cancer.org/Cancer/BreastCancer/DetailedGuide/breast-cancer-staging?rnav=cri ER+, PR+ and HER+ tell you about little receptor thingies on the surface of the tumour cells which determine what it likes to grow on (and therefore what you need to deprive it of, in order to reduce growth) : oestrogen, progesterone, and human epidermal R?? respectively something i forgotten that you trreat with Herceptin. What that does is tells the oncologists the best way to treat. So for ER+ tumours they use treatments that reduce the circulatiung oestrogen or block it from catching onto those receptors: Tamoxifen, aromatase are common ways to do this or removal of ovaries. Staging is made up of a combination of tumour size, whether it has spread to nodes, local structures like muscles or further afield like your liver/lungs/brain, but tells you little about the agressiveness of the tumour. Stage 0 is DCIS or LCIS in-situ pre-cancer, very early stage with high success rates, stage IV or 4 is advanced and bad. Grade on the other hand tells you how aggressive the tumour is, are the cells very wierd or only just a little bit odd: nearly normal cells make a grade 1 tumour, not very aggressive wherease grade 3 is faster growing, more out of control and the cells look very different than normal. Grade 1 is good. You might also hear about an "Oncotype DX" score, that is a test done on biopsy, and is similar to the grade and helps the oncologist decide whether chemo will help for your particular cancer., you can get high medium or low scores (low is good) Hope that helps you. It sounds like they are doing thorough investigations and getting things moving, so I hope you will find out more soon. It's easy to focus on getting the primary tumour out, but that might not be the whole story so time spent doing the extra checks is not time wasted. I spent four months before surgery being treated systemically whole body with tamoxifen (Im ER+) so if any cells had gotten away in my bloodstream whatever, they were also being mopped up, it drove me nuts waiting at the time, but in hindsight it was a good call.

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2011 11:13AM - edited Jun 7, 2011 02:02PM by hymil Gillovski Im a little confused whether you are actually worried about a lump at the moment or just concerned about the standards of care in the UK compared to that in Jordan and anywhere else you have been treated. I'm sorry your friends outcomes. Standard of care in the UK is mammography screening every three years from 50 (now falling to 47) to 70, existing breast care patients are usually recalled annually for five years follow up but this may vary in your area. Over 70 can opt in but will not be called. For a first breast-lump-related visit to GP, the guideline is that if the GP can feel your lump and you are over forty, you will get an urgent referral to be seen at the specialist centre within a fortnight, at which you should get triple assessment: mammogram + fine-needle aspiration + ultrasound and you should go home that day with a definitive diagnosis although for a few of us the FNA may be inadequate you may need a small biopsy or there may be difficult to interpret histology etc and you might have to wait a week for final outcome. Which is the pits. Once you are "in the system" as a known patient, there is then a quick re-entry process eg If i went to my GP tomorrow with another lump, I would be seen again very quickly and I imagine this would also apply to you once your BC history is known. If you let them know sooner rather than wait till you have a problem, they could probably try and get hold of your previous notes/xrays if possible. The screening system is not without its glitches: i recieved a routine invitation to the mobile mass-screening while awaiting my appointment for one year follow from the oncology centre, it seems the national system has no mechanism to link with the specialists, eg it doesn't automatically exclude the breastless!!  I think if i had had a bilateral instead of uni and wasn't concerned about monitoring the other side, I would have gone along just to see their faces.. I think it's the same sort of programme that invites 103 year olds to register for pre-school... then having had a CT scan telling me my pelvis was normal they got upset because i haven't had cervical screening for a while...  You do need to find your way out of the one-size-fits-all approach to get what you need.

Premenopausal ladies can't take Aromasin because the ovaries still produce most of their oestrgoen

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2010 01:48PM hymil wrote: One aspect is that so far you have had surgery without clean margins, so there could be nasties floating free, looking for somewhere to regrow, and you probably want to prevent that. The other aspect is that your team won't meet these tumours very often: my oncologist in a big city sees maybe five new cases a year, and most of those are fifteen years older than me, so it helps to give them time to do their homework. You are quite right to challenge and try to personalise your care away from a standard one-size-fits-all package if it doesn't feel right for you: You will probably still have this body long after they have reitred! I challenged my onc's suggestions, and we negotiated I would come back in a fortnight after he had a chance to contact a few colleagues to ask what they would do, and was better able to listen to the advice as a result. Doesn't mean I took it all! The third thing is I have been told about mucinous tumours that the regrowth pattern is most likely in the same breast and next most likely in the other breast, so chest wall rads which i did and good surveilllance (mammos ect) which i will now be getting, is good cover for this risk, and personally i chose not to subject my whole body to extra hazards. It's cowering under an assault of exercise and better diet instead! I don't think a doctor can really make a decision like that for you. There is information out there, but it takes a bit of perseverance to find it. You are not alone in this.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 05:07PM hymil wrote: LorieG, you have come so far in eight months, and you will be further on next time he asks. Well done. I think it's a common question at this sort of age, my Grandma died (aged 83) when daughter was about this age and she wanted to know, Will we see her? Just curiosity, she wanted to know what do dead people look like? I said No dear, Grandma's body is in a box to keep it clean in the ground, but she doesn't need it anymore because it didn't work and it was hurting her, she is happy now. We are Christians, so I also said Grandma is happy now with Jesus, and he is going to give her a good new body that works fine, that doesn't hurt and she can run and play, but i don't think that meant very much to daughter, although it did explain why Grandma wasn't here to talk to us, as much as if she had gone to stay with uncle Fred, which a child that age can understand. I also explained some people at the funeral were sad because Grandma had gone away, so we would talk more at home so we didn't upset these people now, and she handled that fine. It really focusses on what you believe, and what your son needs - mostly he needs that you will be there for him, which you most likely will be, and you have filled his life with others who will help too.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 08:31PM hymil wrote: No no, with respect I disagree. Overweight is defined as "10kg heavier than me" I learnt that at work from a doctor, true story, On a study day about manual handling, no less, so it must be true. Too many overweight people around these days he said. Bet he wished he had gone into bariatric surgery, not teaching  By the same token, middle aged is "10 years older than me" and I am now 50. (Beat you Iago, by two weeks! Errrr, eeeek, how did that happen??) He, the wise doctor lecturing, was considerably older than me BTW, and a good deal fatter. So having left my childhood somewhere in the dark ages, or maybe in the loft, I had better get on with some adultery before i pass directly into premature senility. See, I still think of myself being about 23. Granted i got a bit less stamina these days and my skin needs ironing.............and chocolate costs a shocking lot more.....  A friend at work told me long ago, "I'm not 63, really I'm nineteen; If I had known i was going to live this long, i would have looked after myself a bit more"   a great motto however long ago your parents started claiming tax relief on you. It's essential to plan your baking strategy in advance. No good having the oven warmed, the eggs whipped, the pan greased lined and floured all ready to go and all the flour sugar etc all measured out, and only then you discover it's ten at night and you've ran out of chocolate - are you really going to get dressed again, fooby wig sleeve eyelashes and whatever other paraphernalia BC has added to your busy life, just to drive to the late-night store so you can finish making those brownies? A hypothetical question requiring no answer. but to those who responded YES of course we are, welcome to my world: I have no sense either! I do have emergency chocolate though, and no day-hike is complete until we have eaten it. Youth IMHO, when it doesn't relate to a lad that DD brings home for [my] supper, is a state of mind, not an unverifiable chronological mistake made before electronic records began. They did have vinyl for records in the era of my purported arrival, EP but not LP ( i was born forceps AKA special-delivery, and in black and white): My parents' generation were born in wax on cylinders, handpainted by candlelight and lucky to be alive with all that cholera diphtheria whooping cough measles and miscellaneous other annoying nasty diseases, and general grinding poverty, and my grandparents' records are on comb-and-paper, if they got born at all. There's no official evidence they all did. So this middle-aged lark, is it a debatable fact about the body you live in, or a state of mind? And inside your mind, reality can be what you want it to be??

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 05:45PM hymil wrote: What comes to my mind when i read your post is two things, fatigue and grief. People tell you about cancer fatigue as a side effect of the illness and treatment; well i didnt understand fatigue I thought it was like tiredness but it isn't. I didn't have it for long, but when I did it was more like a protracted weariness, running out of oomph after taking it well for so long, and it sounds like that's where you are now. You really have been through it, soldiering on at work despite everything, but eventually you just get burnt out on it all. There's a good page on it here (and the links): http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Livingwithandaftercancer/Symptomssideeffects/Fatigue/Fatiguecancer.aspx   Grief, thats a process of loss and subsequent adjusting, we are facing with the loss of reliability of our bodies and being thrust into a world where we are the mercy of others, might not be able to keep on earning wages and we don't know what's round the corner. Physically you and i may have had an easier ride than many other BC sufferers but the mental challenge is still there, and with the fatigue as well. It's fine to be kind to yourself, lots of us are here with BC today because we were not kind enough to ourselves in the past and were too busy putting everyone else first. If you can't be kind to a friend when she has BC, when can you be, and now that friend is you. Does it help to know there's a medical reason to be depressed, you are not cracking up, you have had a life threatening illness and a very scarey time. But you are still here, and you will get through this.

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2011 12:32PM - edited Aug 20, 2011 12:34PM by hymil Love that story. Perspective is just SO important. Reminded me of this one: In the developed world, the rich bit where we have laptops and the internet and food in the fridge, and electricity most days, for us the chief cause of LE is surgery for breast cancer. And we get cross at the surgeons for doing their best. Worldwide however, the commonest cause of LE is not nice clean surgery by highly trained professionals, but a parasitic worm that gets in through walking in dirty water, (because you have flooded "streets", no wellies and no sewers) it burrows in and finds your lymph system, settles down and makes a good living off your body fluids, it grows and grows and grows until the lymphatics get blocked, then you get LE usually in both legs, because there's a massive worm inside of you EWWWW,  GROSS, I would rather have had cancer and its treatments ANY day than that. Shows something else about perspective too, that I thought your post would be about high tech mobile phones....  I love going fruit-picking, try to get out at least once a year to celebrate summer.

Whereas the whole reason my BC nurse didn't give me a regular prosthesis eight months ago after i healed and finished rads, is that she was showing me disgusting dark-peach coloured wrinkly things that just sat there flobbering on the desk and reminded me like lumps of raw liver eeuwwch!! Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2010 10:57AM hymil wrote: thank you for this thread, it's just what i need today. thank you all for your stories too. I'm exactly a year out from diagnosis and finished all active treatment 4th May this year: so I'm now [ NED / in remission / cautiously optimistic ] , and trying to move on with my life. On my way back from seeing the onco last friday, I found a great book (it would be more accurate to say the book found me) by a young guy who had survived bowel cancer against the expectations of his medical tream, he wrote it at pretty much the same stage I'm now at, and he also raises these questions. Latest update I can find is that he was still alive and very well last autumn at nine years out. For him it's a matter of faith that God has cured him. "It's finished, don't look back." I love his approach, I admire his faith and the way he has noved on. I'm very glad for him and his wife that he stays well, and is released from the constant fear of looking over his shoulder waiting in case it comes back, but it does raise so many questions. I'm really strugggling with this. Great if I'm cured, but then so why am I bothering with all the hassle of losing my [sadly under-appreciated] loveable-cuddliness, severely rationing my chocolate like there's a war on, and spending so much time at the gym that "Jim" shoudl really be my better half, why am i bothering to fight oestrogen? I say it's to do with changing the chemical makeup so that any stray cells will meet a hostile environment and not grow easily, but actually... Frankly it's illogical, it's because i chose not to do tamoxifen and will really have egg on my face if the thing does recur. Doing something, anything, creates an illusion of control, when in reality the long drives i do each two or three weeks are a much more present and acute threat to my wellbeing. I can't imagine that i will still be gym-hogging in ten years time! I have the same issue with aged relatives who would just worry if they knew I have had cancer: being practical so long as I outlive them it doesn't matter if im cured, what matters is not letting them down by expecting to be allowed skip out of visiting duties!

Didn't bother with my brain hahaha. What i went through in surgery has hopefully removed the Ca from my body, insurance policy Rads treatment to chest wall,  so I consider it has been worth it. Now, to put myself through all that and NOT be able to say, Well at least the cancer is gone, that's another story and I wouldn't be doing that myself. i would be asking a lot more questions before the drastic steps - like if it has already spread, (as you know that it has) then what difference does taking off a breast make? It sure makes you miserable and sore, so does it make you live longer or better? I like the suggestion of a second opinion, and maybe a third!

Posts.Content: May 17, 2010 12:28PM hymil wrote: MHP, a list of what you need is not mean, it's a great idea. We're happy with wedding lists aren't we, otherwise every newlywed would end up with forty toasters and no spoons! Also a specific wish-list will help separate those who do want to help but are not sure how, from well-wishers who just want to do that and no more. So. Example. Tuesday 5pm, please can someone collect Johnny from football at Queens Park ground. (every Tuesday till August 4th would be even more fantastic!) Would love it if anyone could iron Fred's 5 work-shirts before Sunday evening please. Does anyone have a spare 6-man tent available for the weekend June 12/13th  Ladies, anyone could lend me your old baggy buttonthrough blouses please, any colour, size 18 or larger. Friends, would your teen love to mow my lawn (can use my ride-on machine if over 14)? etc At least it might focus your own mind and prioritise on what NEEDS doing, what you would so love for someome else to do, what would you choose if you could PAY to get just one job off your hands and done for ever....  dream your dreams, and then ask for them! "Dear Santa..."

Janie, I am shocked by that one - Unashamed ageism at its worst!  it's not like you're 85 and only got maybe 15 years ahead of you... Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 07:39PM - edited Sep 2, 2011 07:52PM by hymil It is all very confusing, and more so if you had neo-adjuvant treatment, then you never really get properly staged. Officially, staging happens at the time of surgery apparently. ??  So even if you had mets and the treatment makes them recede and disappear by the time of surgery, you are then classed without them in the same staging-group as people who never had them, HOW WIERD!!  But also because mucinous tumours are "large for dates" to use a baby analogy, LOL, size really isn't everything.  They initially told me the nodes were okay; then at surgery I had a very close chest wall margin (basically zero but not, they said, actually infiltrated ....  yet -??) and also one of the nodes was not as nice as it could have been; although they were calling it clear, there were signs that it had been bad earlier before the neo-adj  So it seems I could have been considered  anywhere 2a-2b-3... can you get locally advanced early stage?? no wonder I'm confused!  I think the TNM classification also helps, as "TNM-300" which is how I'm labelling myself (as mental shorthand for the various combined possibilities of  T2-3,N0-+,M0) is a fairly unusual combination,.but it's the M0 that makes the biggest difference. No mets today, please and thankyou!

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 05:55PM hymil wrote: Gosh Chrissy you have been through the mill! What a survivor! Yes i firnly believe stress can cause BC. The two nicest things the doctors said about me this year are, "She has made a splendid recovery from surgery" and "She has no risk factors for BC". Well, that's not strictly true as I'm female, and at diagnosis last year I had a BMI 29 was a bit of a couch potato, and I had failed to breastfeed beyond eight days due to my own medical postnatal problems. But it did feel such a relief being told this BC is not a direct consequence of something I had done. Medigal, That's not a dig at you or HRT and I do wish I could be able to take it but now I wont be able to, as I'm ER+ too, so if I live long enough from the BC I will probably follow mum into osteoporosis instead. It's a reflection that Dad got lung Ca only four years ago but he had smoked fifty years, and he had to deal with regrets and recriminations as well as all the medical stuff .LIke my family doctor said, We all have 20/20 hindsight and at the time they didnt know all the risks..... Now as for stress however, those doctors had no idea the stress i have dealt with over fifteen, twenty years or so. I didnt ask for erratic hormones, i didnt set out to get divorced or raise a child on my own or take on the wrath of my [previous!] church as a result, i didnt plan to have sole responsibility for mum when Dad passed away or do all the choosing a nursing home stuff without help from sis, and If I had known i would have to do it on my own I could have been living a whole lot closer and saved a wellfull of petrol not zooming across the country every other week. My occupation is well known for stress too although I managed to avoid too much responsibility, but only by staying at a lower paid grade which obviously has stressful financial implications, particularly when Ex decided to quit paying child-maintenance while baby was well too young to earn her own way. No, I don't think the doctors even asked about stress, or maybe they didnt care. It's not something they can change, and anyway it's history, they have to deal with the person in front of them as they find her. But in the absence of any other factors.... i think it was definitely my trigger. They have shown that stress lowers your immune system, and that normally we all have loads of little tiny cancer-seeds but that the healthy immune system normally blots up most ot them. So what to do with it? I already do what I can to limit stress, i've done the chill-out and the time management and the assertiveness and the SWOT (strengths weakness opprotunities challenges) analyses and the Myers-Briggs and pretty much anything else apart from hypnosis or acupuncture. Quitting work is not an option. Marrying a millionaire... well, with half a cleavage that's looking increasingly unlikely...  At the moment I'm becoming an exercsie-endorphin junkie just trying to feel I got some control over my body, my life. Hmmm  I almost convinced myself, but not quite. Fun and laughter I'm working on (see my millionaire comment above!) and i'm also perfecting the art of making lemonade. There are a few practical things i can do like asking for help with my computer/connexion problems, and spending time with friends instead of spending the evening just me and the vacuum cleaner, especially relaxed low-stress friends,  and also Im trying to steer a course of least regrets and then not beat myself up for bad choices made on limited information. Being positive is hard but, like love, it's a decision not a feeling, so here goes: girls, your pictures look lovely, Chrissy I'm sending you a bucket-load of cyber-lemons and we can sell the produce!
